title: Drive Overspeeding
statement:
Alice is going for a drive. During her drive, she reached a maximum speed of S km/hr.

As per the rules of the government, the speed of the vehicle must not exceed 40 km/hr, otherwise the person will be fined.

You need to tell whether Alice will be fined or not.
input: The only line of input will contain a single integer S - denoting the maximum speed Alice reached while driving.
output:
Print YES if Alice will be fined , otherwise print NO.

You may print each character of the string in uppercase or lowercase (for example, the strings YES, yEs, yes, and yeS will all be treated as identical).

samples.explanation: Since Alice's speed does not exceed 40, she will not be fined.
Since Alice's speed exceeds 40, she will be fined.

title: Even or Odd
statement: Given an integer N, determine whether it is even or odd.
input: The only line of input will contain a single integer N.
output: Print EVEN if N is even, otherwise print ODD.

samples.explanation: 4 is an even number.
-7 is an odd number.

title: Factorial
statement: Given a non-negative integer N, compute its factorial.
input: The only line of input will contain a single integer N (0 ≤ N ≤ 20).

samples.explanation: 0! = 1 by convention.

title: Sum of Digits
statement: Given an integer N, compute the sum of its digits.
input: The only line of input will contain a single integer N (0 ≤ N ≤ 10^9).
output: Print the sum of the digits of N.

samples.explanation: The sum of the digits of 12345 is 1+2+3+4+5 = 15.
The sum of the digits of 987654321 is 9+8+7+6+5+4+3+2+1 = 45.

title: Reverse Number
statement: Given an integer N, reverse its digits.
input: The only line of input will contain a single integer N (0 ≤ N ≤ 10^9).
output: Print the reverse of the digits of N.

samples.explanation: The reverse of the digits of 12345 is 54321.
The reverse of the digits of 100 is 001, which is 1.

title: Prime Number
statement: Given an integer N, determine whether it is a prime number or not.
input: The only line of input will contain a single integer N (1 ≤ N ≤ 10^6).
output: Print YES if N is a prime number, otherwise print NO.

samples.explanation: 17 is a prime number.
10 is not a prime number.

title: Square Root
statement: Given a non-negative integer N, compute its square root.
input: The only line of input will contain a single integer N (0 ≤ N ≤ 10^9).
output: Print the square root of N with an absolute error less than or equal to 10^-6.

samples.explanation: The square root of 25 is 5.
The square root of 0 is 0.

title: Binary to Decimal
statement: Given a binary number as a string, convert it to its decimal representation.
input: The only line of input will contain a string of length N (1 ≤ N ≤ 10^3) consisting of '0's and '1's.
output: Print the decimal representation of the given binary number.

samples.explanation: The binary number 1010 is equivalent to 10 in decimal.
The binary number 1111 is equivalent to 15 in decimal.

title: Fibonacci Series
statement: Given an integer N, print the first N terms of the Fibonacci series.
input: The only line of input will contain a single integer N (1 ≤ N ≤ 100).
output: Print the first N terms of the Fibonacci series separated by spaces.

samples.explanation: The first 5 terms of the Fibonacci series are 0, 1, 1, 2, 3.
The first 8 terms of the Fibonacci series are 0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13.

title: Find Maximum
statement: Given an array of integers, find the maximum element in the array.
input: The first line of input contains an integer N (1 ≤ N ≤ 10^5) representing the size of the array. The second line contains N integers separated by space.
output: Print the maximum element in the array.

samples.explanation: The maximum element in the array [1, 4, 6, 3, 8] is 8.
The maximum element in the array [-5, -1, -10] is -1.

title: Count Vowels
statement: Given a string S, count the number of vowels (a, e, i, o, u) in the string.
input: The only line of input contains a string S (1 ≤ |S| ≤ 10^3).
output: Print the count of vowels in the string.

samples.explanation: The string 'programming' contains 3 vowels: o, a, and i.
The string 'hello' contains 2 vowels: e and o.
